review:
It was decent, played a few games (which apparently took 8 hours, huh...)

Its similar to FTL in that randomness plays a big role. Single events can either destroy or save you from a seemingly unescapable situation. I dont know whether this is a good or bad thing. It does prevent boredom and makes every playthrough different. But on the other hand, playing 'correctly' is not enough to succeed, which might lead to frustration if you just want to get your hands on the nukes (which I never did ;_;).

There seemed to be many possible events (of a few possible types, like every turn, or special events that I only faced once in the entire session)

General atmosphere was nice.

What I disliked:
-Too much randomness to my taste, needs more meaningful played choice. More ability to REACT to random events instead of just attempting to anticipate them (which is just a guess for whether that particular action will prove to be useful)
-Cannot completely skip animations (you can click twice to skip most of it, but you cant skip ALL of it), kind of irritating once youve done the same thing 50 times
-Not enough choices (less randomness would be required for more choices to work I think), like more countries, more detailed war system...

author: {'steamid': '76561197978610292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1445158629}
review:
Rogue State... the humoristic post-revolution country management simulator.

A nice idea, layout and attempt to deliver a realistic experience but the game have not what it takes to give us sufficient interest and life span.

[Game refunded: Review won't be updated]

[h1] Plot:[/h1] 
The revolution is over and King Salman is dead. You are the leader of the new government of Basenji: a fictive country of Middle East based on the name of a dog. It's up to you to restore the pride and power of your state and create a reign that last for thousand years... 

[h1] Graphics:[/h1] 
The intro is nice, based on pictures well drawn. The game takes place in your office and situation room. Every selections of menus makes your avatar ( a man or a women) move across the rooms and open/use appropriates elements related to menus. The game looks nice, only characters are a bit "frozen" and loose in realism. Something very nice is the presence of a newspaper. You can check some important info  and every headlines feature photographs depending of recent news. The only really problematic thing about newspaper is the color of text. When some white letters are on black and white photos it lacks in transparency!

[h1] Music:[/h1] 
Nice oriental tunes that stick to the atmosphere of the tile. Voice acting is correct but not impressive. Nothing special to say about this aspect of the game.


[h1] Controls:[/h1] 
Choosing the office of the character is a good and a bad idea. Especially if any menu selections forces you to wait for your avatar to move and activate the selected item related to it. Need to check relations and trade? Select the phone and wait your man or women to take it. Need to read newspapers... wait him or her to cross the room to open it. Ect... ect... ect... Very annoying especially about trading and diplomacy. But let's talk about gameplay would you.

[h1] Gameplay (the long part) :[/h1] 
You are the leader of a so called Rogue State. After having created your president/future dictator, you must appoint your ministers and your brother Farouk to vacant roles.
The first issue of the game is the presence of Farouk, a general famous in the revolution and loved by the people.
You can't trust him and sacrifice a part of your ministry for him. Considering he's a burden, you are forced to put him in the worst job: intelligence. Every other seat are important and quite early shows the limits of the game:
Lacks of information (funny when you think that intelligence is a dark and useless aspect of the game).

So you have 3 others politicians, randomly generated and members of 1 of the factions of the country: Patriots, Capitalists, Fundamentalists and Liberals.

The game acts around turns where you have to do actions and try to give the best of the time you have at disposal.  To manage factions you have to choose Policies and try to balance popularity between every faction. In general to please your people acts around reading the newspapers to see how much percent of factions compose your country and after you try to balance the most important ones and please them with buildings and ministry favors. Consider that policies can change from a turn to another without any drawbacks and you have a first clue of how simplistic the game is.

But this is not all because in Rogue State you can build things... 
At beginning you must rebuild the country and industries. Few choices with not much impact crosses your path, like amnesty for previous members of brought down government or not. This part sum up quite badly the reconstruction of a country after war. When done you can produce 2 resources and access to 3 panels: Army, Social, and Economic.

Very simple, a building rarely give permanent bonuses and quite often asks for a lot of funds to give a one-time bonus that might be spoiled by a random event. Because events are common in the game.

Indeed every turn has events, completely random that influence factions, popularity and loyalty.
Very often you have to sacrifice a faction and even pay lot of money to get rid of these unpleasant events. 40 % of your country is full of capitalists? Only focus on money and do not care of environmental events.
Many fundamentalists? Nevers authorize western corporations in your country. Ect… ect...
Extremely boring, it is amazing to see ridiculous events such as the Meteorite when if you have a space program... you can put a device on it and change its course... But if you don't it will blow one of you buildings.
Goodbye freshly built Stadium! Goodbye Sweetshop!
Ridiculous.

But that's not all. A building requires money. You can trade with the 3 neighbor country bordering your country.
You take your phone and give a call to each leader to find the best prices and sign contracts for export or import.
Resources are random and very often you won't have the one you need to please your factions.
Of course good relations gives better prices, also the market influences the prices.
But to know what kind of resource your neighbor needs depends of intelligence... and if you remember that intelligence is a completely unexplained element.
Add to that the fact that every phone calls uses one of the 4 segments of time that composes a turn... you bet that trades are horribly basic and falls into boredom very quickly.


Rogue State tries to play at war too. That's why the situation room is right next to your office...
You can buy troops, influenced by Army buildings in terms of price and deployment time. Each unit has attack and defense. And of course, the more powerful the more expensive.
There is a situation map where you can move your "pawns" and declare war but without any infos about attackers or how to manage fights.
You can also manage intelligence and secret projects that takes time and money but bring (apparently) very powerful effects... but you won't have time to see them finished.

Because: You remember of Farouk ? Your dear brother waits a moment of weakness to turn upside down your government.
And it's where the game fall into a waste of time because you are forced to mass tons of units and rally many favors to temporary slow the revolution prepared by Farouk (don't forget to click on the button on top right because the game doesn't even takes time to explain this...).

It is so empty and baffling that i never succeeded to survive this moment.
Even if i had 3 factions pleased and a nice popularity but not much money... i've lost the game.

Because in Rogue State you build, makes your country a safer place by building tons of institutions and nobody gives a @@@ about it. Even taxes are unexplained and you can tax 50 % of your income and know absolutely nothing about its effects of the population....

Ridiculous.


[h1] TO CONCLUDE:[/h1] 

Rogue State is a disappointment. Too simplistic, the game falls very quickly into boring text reading and random events that causes havoc into your miserable tries.
Even managing your ministry is a joke where ministers acts stupidly and asks for ridiculous actions.
[i]"Move units to this country border!»[/i] Even if there nothing wrong with them! [i]"Arrange a meeting with the President of The United States in few months"[/i]... and you don't know how to do it even if you invite dozens of time an ambassador with your lame speech...
Foreign diplomatic relationships where you have to wait for intelligence that never comes or so basic trade options that any decent management game wouldn't have dare to mix a camel/pony looking animal with a water bottle to create fast food that will make religious fundamentalists upset but Capitalists happy...

The most incredible thing in Rogue State are TV speech which are completely useless and empty.

Rogue State is a shame that shows peoples of middle-east as stupid and incoherent where random elements cripples a gameplay that could have been great.


Too bad.

I came really close to not recommending this game. The conecpt behind it is very well thought out. It was fun, but i would say that this game lacks major polishing. There was also i bug that appeared after about 2hrs of play. Random dialogue sections would skip, and your character would immediately jump to whatever you clicked on.  With the way the graphics are (retro graphics from the 90's? kind of appealing) and the lack of content and its diversity i would put this game at mid to late beta stage. 

With some more work from the dev's this could become a real gem. I get the sense that dev's really liked this game but either had to much on their plate, or they wanted to rush this game out "as is" for some money. At a $9.74 pricetag i can say im not disappointed that i spent this much money, however i expect some more content, and a clearer set of instructions. (i could not find out how to sell military items instead of disbandment). This game is far to short to be considered more than a flash game.
 

I give this game a 5.5/10 great first try, i hope to play this after an update or some such. (dont you dare try to charge me more money for DLC, in fact, dont even offer me any this would prove to me your intentions)

EDIT: Also the military system is lacking. If i am attacked, i expect my military to have a report on our loses, (predicted) Enemy losses, and the enemy units that attacked. Anytime you use the military system, you are essentialy blind. Morale is a huge part of combat, if my miltarys morale is high i expect them to fight far better then if their morale is Meh. Also, ive had situations where an enemy makes peace, then immediately after attacks. As a side note, if i have excellent relations with the U.S. i expect some major help from them, in addition to other nations with poor relations with the attacker.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012469834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1446698906}
review:
Rogue State fills a specific niche very well - very challenging, procedurally generated( never the same twice), self aware, and valuing content over presentation/story. At it's core it is a strategic political simulation game putting you in charge of a middle eastern country.  There are also strong emphasis on survival over crafting the your country as you see fit.  Surviving is difficult, and unlike other mangement survival games like Long Live the Queen there is some randomness, which can ruin the experience for some, but it also increases replayability. Many things threaten your survival, revolts from factions within your populace (patriots, liberals, captialists, and fundamentalists), your power hungry brother, your military, your own government's cabinet, your neigbors, democratic rebellions, disease, envnironment and financial crises, and even the meddling United States.  It may take several playthroughs to see all of these threats, and the most problematic threat to your power is almost never the same on back to back new games.

Though random, you do have hints to what you should focus on that are simple to miss, such as paying attention to random events, analyzing the breakdown of people who are in each faction or using information gained through your intelligence agency. However, that being said there are some good things that are always good -  keeping a large surplus of money around of diasters and investing into your economy and social programs with somewhat high taxes.   I also like how this game can be subtle.  You are actually a dictator and one of the scenarios confirms this when a group threatens your regime with a democratic revolution.  This is easy to overlook because the game rewards you for being a benevolent dictator, and the absence of elections during the whole game is easier to miss than you think when the game doesn't paint you as the stereotypical evil dictator.

 This game may turn off some with its unpolished retro graphics and empasis on strategy over a story, but I believe it targets a specific target demographic well.  If you are ready for challenege, can overlook a somewhat dated presentation, and are aware this is more of a survival/management game that rewards for you playing to the situation faced rather than roleplaying as you see fit, this is the game for you.

Really can't recomend this. The gameplay is too simple. The animations are slow and some can't be skipped, so annoying. The devs seem to have balanced policies (and the "papers" policy unlocks) how they think they are, not what they really do. A lot of the policy papers unlock "bad" things, like weapons dealing and counterfeiting goods and money. 
While the gameplay is too simple, there are looots of menues and screens to figure out. All with those dumb animations between opening them. At regular intervals you make speeches to the people, and can make promises, but you can only fulfil those promises if a random event pops up that gives the option. There is no education spending policy?

All in all, this game doesn't simulate anything resembling a real country, just has random events and odd policy areas (read: budget expense policies). Maybe younger gamers may like it, but it will not give any educational benefit in how countries are actually run.

review:
[h1] Overall Rogue State is a fun, and challenging game! However... [/h1]

Rogue State is a game where you rule over a middle eastern country, as a democratic ruler.
[spoiler] Really? No ability to rule as a dictator/monarch? I understand what the game is generally going for, ruling a democratic nation in the middle east. Just feels dissapointing that you cannot rename/change your nation's name or flag. Or that you cannot change your government type. [/spoiler]

You must manage 4 classes, which represent your overall population.
[spoiler] These four classes will randomly become more important/bigger during certain times in the game, such as a rising number of capitalists, or patriots. This is sadly random, and you have NO way of influencing the population to becoming more loyal to your prefered population. [/spoiler]

As well, you must manage local diplomacy, negotians with the US, and the UN.
[spoiler] As unique as it is, having randomly picked nations to be your neighbors is intersting, your bound to enter war with one. You need a strong army, or your going to be crushed. Fast. [/spoiler]

You must rebuild your country's infanstructure (AKA, Tech tree.)
[spoiler] Though fun, it is quite basic, and it definently sometimes feels unuseful, or game changing. [/spoiler]

You must manage your country's policies to meet the expectations.
[spoiler] It is almost impossible for everyone to like you, and your going to end up having revolutions appearing. [/spoiler]

Unique 'wonder' projects, such as a great firewall, space program, nukes, Great Dam.
[spoiler] I call them wonders, because they are essentially the wonder buildings from Civilization. [/spoiler]

Protect your glorious nation against coups and civil wars!
[spoiler] Doesn't give you much in-depth on what is actually going on in the coup. Besides that, you just need lots of soldiers, and you are sort of REQUIRED to fill out these little bonuses which will aid in fighting back the rebels. (Such as, building a great Firewall, having high relations with the US.) [/spoiler]

Random Events every turn, constantly changing how your population reacts to certain policies, how much money you make/spend, and diplomatic changes.
[spoiler] These feels EXTREMELY random, and sometimes, being bombarded by certain similar events one after another, seem unfair. It's more of a luck game, then a strategy game. [/spoiler]

Overall, the game is good, a 7/10. It's a basic country ruling simulator, that is a bit unforgiving at times, as it can sometimes throw constant situations and events at you that make it impossible to stay alive for more then 20 turns. If your into roleplaying as a leader, go for it.

- Long Live the Queen.



[h1] Unsimilar games [/h1]

-Bad Rats

author: {'steamid': '76561197977024078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1445024387}
review:
My review may be slightly biased as I had the opportunity to BETA test this game early on through to release. I've seen it grow into the immersive, challenging, and beautifully addictive simulation that it is now. I think that's a key point to make here - this may look like a game but it's more akin to a 'strategy simulation'. There is no 'easy win' path that, once discovered, works each time. 

Some of the other reviews here cover the main mechanics so I'll keep this short. The game is loaded with random events inspired by real life meaning that each play through is always different. You play with the hand you're dealt and see how the cards fall.  Certainly, the good decisions you make and the tools you implement along the way will help to swing things in your favour - be it a change in policies or a perfectly pitched national broadcast - but you can never please all of the people all of the time and the randomness of real life can quickly change your fortunes if you react wrongly. Then, of course there's your scheming brother Farouk to contend with. 

This is almost a survival simulator as much as it is a strategy title - the goal being to stay in power for as many turns as possible. Some times you'll win, most times you probably won't - but you'll have a darn good time trying... because once you get comfortable in the dictators chair you'll be itching for the next turn... and the next... and the next... which seems to me an accurate reflection of the life of a dictator, and the hallmark of a good game.

Just make sure to siphon off enough funds to enjoy your retirement... if you make it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984805488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1446965501}
review:
I received an early copy of Rogue State and have been playing it (primarily off Steam) for a while now.  

The game is a turn-based strategy simulator of a middle-eastern dictatorship with deep, interconnecting mechanics.  Each session of the game is very different: your neighbours, the distribution of goods, your ministers, and most importantly the events that will occur are randomized, and this has made each playthrough very different and interesting.  

The graphics in the game are, admittedly, retro, but the artwork is very well done and the animations are clean.  For a turn-based strategy game, it does the trick.

The writing of the game is often funny, and the voice acting is very good (and everything is voiced).  

Rogue State is admittedly very challenging, but I like a challenge.  Managing the support of the four factions in your country, managing your budget, and managing the production of infrastructure and special projects is a tricky balancing act, and early on, I lost often.  However, when I won, I felt like I really earned it!  I found that I could get further and further on each playthrough as I figured out how to better keep everyone (or everyone that mattered) happy without going totally broke.

This game has that "one more turn" compulsion that I get with Civ.  I recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198079595906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1444738371}
review:
FULL DISCLOSURE: I received a free copy of this game prior to release for review. It is your right to disregard my criticism as invalid because of this fact. That said, I assure you that this has never affected, and will never affect, any of the content of my reviews.

[h1]What is Rogue State?[/h1]
Rogue State is a management game, where you play as the leader of a middle eastern country. The whole idea is that you led the rebellion, man or woman, that overthowed a previous tyrannical power, and the people look to you to rebuild, and propel the country into prosperity. It is procedurally generated, with new countries, ministers, and events each game -- but there is one major constant that is present in every single game; your brother Farouk. He will be trying to undermine everything you do, and if you let your popularity dwindle Farouk will make his move and take over leadership by force. In addition to this you might have to deal with war, environmental and social issues, terrorism, financial crises, debt and more, so there’s a lot to pay attention to.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
I’m gonna begin this review at rock bottom. This game is presented abhorrently. It looks and plays like it was made 20 years ago. I mean, I don’t think there is any aspect of this game that couldn’t have been done in the 90s. Maybe aside from the resolution. In addition to the aesthetic issues, it played in a 4:3 aspect ratio and 30 fps and I don’t think it’s possible to go any higher than that. To me this reeks of trying to be overly-ambitious with the visuals; personally I think a top down pixel approach definitely wouldn’t be anything special, but it would be a lot cleaner and palatable than this; just as an example. If I try and twist it into a positive, then maybe you’d like the presentation if you have nostalgia for 90s point and click games? That’s the kind of visual vibe I get from it.

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
Presentation is important, but it can be completely overruled by solid mechanics. I thought about this for a while, but I think the best description of what this game is like, is Long Live the Queen but randomly generated. I feel like, at first, that seems appealing to Long Live the Queen fans (which I’m one of by the way, I loved that game) but actually that makes the game extremely challenging. I feel like if you knew everything in advance that was going to happen, you could maybe beat this game and reach the final turn 50. However, since you don’t know anything that’s going to happen, other than a few key events,  it becomes a game of luck rather than one of strategy. Everything can be going perfectly for you, but if suddenly you have a terrorist problem and you have to begin putting money into the intelligence agency, you can quickly find yourself in debt and you reach a point where, even if you stop the terrorists, your country hates you and Farouk takes over. This is compounded by the fact you are constantly pressured into spending money in the events that occur every turn. It’s very hard to deal with these situations when you are given such a tiny timeframe to combat them in. One of the more cool mechanics, though,  is that you have to make a speech every year and you pick what the leader says in the speech. Again, it’s cool, you have to make sure you don’t contradict yourself and stay relevant,  but even then it does get repetitive and eventually I just found it unreliable and clicked through it out of boredom. There are some fun ideas here, but ultimately everything is tainted by that unfair difficulty.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is really just furniture, but the theme is pretty interesting to me. I like that you have the opportunity to run the country in whatever way you please. It’s a pretty good role-play game I think. There’s some social commentary mixed in with the turn-by-turn events which is interesting, and there's some pretty funny writing here and there. There’s a potential neighbouring country you can have called Chickenstan, and you can unlock a perk which allows you to understand the ancient chickenstan language. I will say that there are a couple of groaners in there in terms of the writing, but I have a suspicion that was what they were going for in those situations.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Now it’s time for me to say whether I think it’s worth it or not. The game is $13 at launch. I’m just going to be blunt; for most people I wouldn't recommend this game. I was kind of joking about this earlier, but if there really are people who are nostalgic for this kind of look, and are really into the idea of role-playing as a middle-eastern leader then yeah sure I’d recommend it -- but I feel like that is an incredibly tiny subset of people. Frankly, you’re only really going to like this if you're big into management games, and even then there are better management games out there. Prison Architect is a great game that allows you to actually build the prison as well as set things like policies, prison schedules etc that offers everything that Rogue State does only better. Even smaller games like Game Dev Tycoon and Long Live the Queen get a bit of an edge over Rogue State. It’s a shame, but that’s the way the cookie crumbles. I'm excited to see more from this developer, but Rogue State is one you’ll probably want to give a miss.
